text:
This is an excellent recipe.  I give it 5 stars and I didnt add the spices like some of the others did.  I didn't want a spice muffin.  I wanted a banana nut recipe and thought this one looked very good with the real butter in the ingredients and by the pictures of it. Be sure to mix the wet ingredients first. The secret is to mix by hand and not to overmix. I added walnuts and mixed it up night before and kept in refrigerator to bake fresh in morning.   Muffins didn't stick to paper liners. Delicious recipe!

text:
These muffins are really great!!  We bake these everytime we have mushy bananas.  I have substituted one individual applesauce cup for the butter and they turn out just as good, but with less fat!!  I usually also add about a 1/2 teaspoon of vanilla and a sprinkle of cinnamon. I always make the mini muffins and you MUST increase the time by several minutes (if you want them golden on top and not mushy).  The kids gobble them up!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is PERFECT!  I wouldn't change a thing about it.  I must admit that I used 3 cups of mashed bananas per batch and I really don't know how many cups 3 large bananas make.    My kids gobbled up these muffins (mini & full size) and I realized I finally found a more convenient (and yummier) "Banana Bread" recipe than the one I had.  These muffins taste exactly like the bread recipe I've been searching for!  Whoever said Banana Bread had to be in loaf form?  :)  Thanks so much!      *TIP*  I always have several bags of frozen mashed bananas on hand.  I used to just freeze the whole banana, but realized it was much easier to mash them up beforehand and portion them at 2-3 cups per Quart Freezer Ziplock bag.  Lay them flat in a 13 x 9 pan and freeze.  Once frozen you can remove them from the pan and store them in the freezer.

text:
these were great!  My kids love them.  I've made them now as standard sized and mini muffins.  My kids like the minis the best.  They were very moist.  I have followed the recipe to a T and they were delicious, but they are also delicious with my alterations.  I've been making them for months now with 1 tsp of cinnamon and 1 tsp of vanilla.  I also add 3/4 cup of mini choc chips sometimes.  But what I mostly like is that I use a combo of mostly wheat flour with a little white.  I use the Splenda baking blend.  I sub no sugar applesauce in place of the butter and I use egg white egg substitute for the eggs.  They are healthier and just a delicious!

text:
I have made these with no changes and they are good that way.  I thought my muffin tin was large because they are bigger than my mini tin, but when they were in the oven for 20 minutes, they were done.  So make sure you watch them!  25-30 minutes may be way too long.  I have a banana everyday for breakfast and as they start to turn I put them in the freezer for bread.  I had a stockpile of 10 bananas to use up.  I came upon this recipe while looking for something new.  I have made a second batch with streusel on top, and a third batch adding vanilla, pecans and 1/4 bag of peanut butter/chocolate chips, using the mini muffin tins.  I must say that from now on, I will be doing that with all my leftover bananas!!!! I definetly loved the mini muffins with the vanilla, pecans and chips so much more!!!  All I can say is.....WOW! They would make a great morning breakfast treat....if they last that long.  You gotta try these!!!! Thanks for a great recipe ABI_GODFREY

text:
I enjoyed this recipe, but made little variations to increase the nutritional value. First off, I used a cup of whole wheat flour and 1/4 cup of oats. I used 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1/4 cup of white sugar. The amount of butter was cut down just a little, and I added 1/4 cup of vegetable oil. With a little vanilla, 1/2 tsp. of cinnamon, and 1/4 tsp. of nutmeg, these muffins turned out pretty good! Next time, I'd go with a little more banana's as well.

text:
I scaled down the recipe to make only 24 mini muffins (8 servings on calculator) as I had only 2 bananas.  It worked out perfectly, filling each cup to the top.  I took the liberty of adding 1/4 tsp. vanilla extract, a pinch of ground cinnamon and 1/4 cup of chopped walnuts.  The muffins baked for exactly 12 minutes.  I'll be making these again with the same proportions and may ice or top with struesel the next time.

text:
This is an AWESOME recipe! My 23 month old and "almost" 4 old had a great time helping. I substituted 3/4 C whole wheat and 3/4 C white flour. In lieu of butter, I used 1/3 C canned pumpkin. The pumpkin is basically undectable, and you are adding in some good vitamins while cutting a few calories. I topped it off with some Pampered Chef sweet apple sprinkle I had on hand. I think next time I will try to sneak in some spinich :) I know, a nasty trick to play on unsuspecting youngsters.

text:
This is a very good recipe. It has more bananas than other recipes which is exactly what I was looking for. The reason these are coming out dry for so many people is that the cooking time is WAY off. At 350, these should be baking for 18 to 20 minutes MAX. Not 25 to 30. I also added some cinnamon and vanilla and these are perfect.

text:
Delicious!  I substitute 4 oz. of unsweetened applesauce + 1 Tbsp of sour cream for the melted butter, add a splash of vanilla extract and a sprinkle of cinnamon, and bake in a non-stick mini muffin pan sprayed lightly with cooking spray (paper liners not needed).  Then I freeze them in snack-size ziploc bags, three to a bag.  In the morning, toss into the kids' lunchboxes and they're thawed by snacktime at school!

I would have given 5 stars if the recipe included 1/2 tsp vanilla, 1/2 tsp cinnamon, a pinch of nutmeg and one more banana.  I made the recipe as-is the first time and it was definitely lacking something.  The extra banana is really necessary to get a nice moist muffin and the spices are common and found in every kitchen so it is foolish to not include something!  My version made 12 med size muffins which I baked 25 mins to perfection.  And, I always use paper liners since it makes cleanup a snap!

When you combine the wet and dry ingredients, DO NOT "beat until smooth".  What this wonderful recipe means to say is "gently fold together".  This will yield fabulous, moist, delicious muffins.

text:
I made a batch of these yesterday - they turned out quite tasty! I added 1/4 cup of walnuts, 1 tsp vanilla,an extra half banana, half brown sugar/half white instead of what the recipe calls for. I think next time I make them I am going to substitute some of the white flour with whole wheat.I found them to be really light and airy and I think the whole wheat flour would make them a little heavier. I would definitely use this recipe again. Thanks!

text:
These were very good, with just a few adjustments.  As recommended by other reviewers, I added 1 tsp vanilla extract, used 1/2 cup light brown sugar and 1/4 cup white sugar, 1 tsp cinnamon, and 1/2 cup chopped walnuts.  Tasted good both hot out of the oven and cool.  Nice light texture and great flavor!  The bananas I used were almost black, very ripe and soft.  My husband, who loves banana nut muffins, thought these were good, and even my picky 4 year old ate one and liked it!  I will make this whenever I have overripe bananas!!  Thanks for the recipe Abi!

I liked these muffins, however I did do a few modifications due to other reviews. country:

text:
Right off the bat, I can say that It SMELLS amazing while baking. Bannanas are so fragrant. Instead of muffins, I baked this in a 8 by 8 square cake pan. I tweaked the recipe to my availability of ingredients. I used half a cup of brown sugar instead of white sugar, and then a generous of tablespoons of honey and drizzled it in after I creamed the butter sugar, egg and bananas into sort of soup. I also used a bit more banana, I used four bananas, two really large ones, and two medium ones. The cake I made turned out dense, fragrant and flavorful. I also added a dash (about a teaspoon) of cocoa powder which tastes AMAZING (a little goes a long way) and also a some walnuts into the batter and i topped the cake off with almond halves for decoration.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
fantastic...I have an old banana bread recipe that is very close to this only this one had a few twists that I liked. This recipe uses less flour, less eggs and more bananas. Someone said they only used 1/2 cup sugar so I did too. I had some walnuts leftover from a Christmas recipe that were already chopped up, so I threw those in. (They had a little cinnamon in them.) The only thing that I really changed was the butter. My old recipe calls for 1/3 cup cooking oil, so I used that instead of the butter. (figured it'd be healthier) I only had enough baking cups for 6 of the muffins, so I made the other half using a little Pam instead. Both ways turned out great. I'll be making these again.

text:
This is a great recipe that holds up well to some substitutions. I use a gluten-free flour substitute. For a healthier muffin, in place of 1/3 cup or butter, I use 1/3 cup of applesauce and 2 table spoons of butter. Sometimes I throw in 2 tablespoons of poppy seeds and they still come out tasting amazing!
The other thing I do is use 1 and a half times the ingredients to make larger muffins. All the same, this recipe deserves 5 stars.

text:
I used half white flour and half whole wheat flour, 4 bananas, and cut the sugar to a little less than 1/2 a cup.  I used Extra Light Olive Oil (can be used for baking and tastes similar to butter with a nutty flavor).  So I would need 4 tablespoons of the Olive Oil...well instead of 4 I used 3 and added 3 tablespoons of Flax seed which replaces a tablespoon of oil.  I also didn't add salt.  I did add 2 tsp of vanilla and 2 tsp cinnamon.  These muffins came out soooo good.  My house smelled of banana muffins!!  Will definitely make again!!

These were great. I love that this recipe is so simple, with on-hand ingredients. I actually only had 1 extremely over-ripe banana, so I added in 2 nectarines (in place of 2 more bananas) that had also seen better days. Since the fruit overall was SO ripe, I cut back the sugar to just 1/2 cup, fearing it might be too sweet...and I found it to be just right. Otherwise, everything stayed the same. I had 1 right out of the oven...it was so good. Then I simply had to have another with a cup of tea immediately after LOL. I'm doing my best to not have a third! What a delightful recipe...will make this one again!

city:

country:
None
text:
These are absolutely the BEST banana muffins I have ever eaten. I used whole wheat flour and I added a dash of vanilla. And I used 3 super ripe bananas. I kept them until the outer skin started turning black, then refrigerated to prevent them from getting mushy. My muffins took 28 minutes at 350 degrees to be perfect. They were golden brown and so moist, sweet and delicious! Do not mash the bananas too much if you want visible bits of banana in your muffins. I also sifted the dry ingredients and I didn't overmix. Wonderful, wonderful, WONDERFUL!!!

text:
One of the best banana muffin recipes that I have found without nuts!  Moist, perfect consistency, great taste.  All four of my kids love these.  One hint:  Leave the batter set for 5-10 minutes before putting it into the muffin tins.  It is much easier to spoon in, not as runny as right after mixing!  Also, the perfect batter consistency (if you let it set) to put into a baggie and pipe into mini muffin tins!

text:
Very moist and very yummy! I'm a really big fan of crusty muffin tops so I used this recipe to make 10 muffins with big crusty tops, instead of 12 as suggested by the recipe (I might make 9 next time for bigger crusty tops). I didn't have any chocolate chips, as suggested by others, so I chopped up 100 grams of Cadbury dark cooking chocolate instead. Very yummy, and surprising quite light as well. Will definitely make it again.

text:
Wow! I'm not usually a banana fan, but we found this to be the best recipe to use those quickly ripening bananas! I'm editing my review after 3 yrs of this being my favorite banana muffin recipe "as is" because over the years I've made a few changes to make it healthier...as suggested in other reviews I substituted applesauce-when I have it for the butter and use the butter Pam spray for the muffin pans for the flavor.  Also, the recipe seems fairly forgiving if I only have 2 bananas or 4.  I've also been able to exchange wheat flour and oat bran for the all purpose flour.  Although I do love cinnamon, this recipe is great whether it's added or not! The best thing I like about using this recipe is that I can make it into mini muffins and it's even quicker than the 25 min cooking time!Thank you so much, Abi!

text:
WOW! so very good!
I changed the recipe a little. I used 100% whole wheat flour instead of white and added 1 tsp of cinnimon. I didn't mash my bananas to mush because i like the little banana chunks in the muffin, and I made 6 jumbo muffins instead of 12 regular muffins.  I baked them at the desired temp. for 25 minutes in my oven and they turned out beautiful. My Husband and I just love them, and the whole wheat flour did not dry them out.  I added a sprinkle of walnuts on top before I baked them and they were just perfect.  I am going to make three batches next time and freeze them for when ever we want them. They didn't last long.  Thank you for the great recipe.

text:
D E L I C I O U S!!  They just came out of the oven, and I couldn't wait until morning to have one.  I did like some others recommended and added some cinnamon & nutmeg.  I was out of vanilla, so I used some almond extract.  I also used 1C white flour and 1/2C whole wheat flour, and reduced the sugar to 1/2C.  Then I added some fresh blueberries.  So I guess I sort of made my own recipe, but this was a great springboard!

Did a healthier version of these and they turned out great!  I replaced one cup of the flour with whole wheat, didn't use any butter, and reduced the sugar to 2/3 cup.  I pureed the really, really ripe bananas in a food processor because I like the texture of banana baked goods better that way.

text:
I made this recipe a week or two ago...super easy, quick, and delicious!  I am Gluten Free (GF) and I was a bit fearful the banana would not cover the "off" taste of GF flour, but it did a pretty good job of it.  Like others I added in 1 tsp cinnamon to the dry ingredients, as well as 1 tsp vanilla and 1/3 cup chopped walnuts.  Delicious!  For left overs, I recommend any one making these GF to warm up the muffin...when eating cold I could taste the GF flour more easily (not as pleasant).

text:
This was my first time ever making muffins, I just knew I really wanted a muffin that would use up my too ripe bananas.  I did not follow the recipe exactly because I didn't have all of the ingredients.  Instead of all purpose flour I used wheat flour, I didn't have any baking soda so I doubled the baking powder, and I probably put in too much sugar.  With all of my "changes" the muffins were still AMAZING. They weren't as pretty (it could be because I overfilled my muffin cups or b/c I didn't have baking soda) but I've learned to "never judge a book by it's cover."

These Muffins were excellent!!!

Very moist and very fragrant.

I made some "healthy" changes and these turned out WONDERFUL!!!  I used 100% spelt flour instead of all-purpose flour. And I used a skimp 1/2 cup honey instead of the sugar. I used only a 1/4 cup butter to balance the extra moisture from the honey.   They get darker sooner but wait until they "bounce back" when touching to see if they are done.

text:
These are phenomenal. I would not buy a banana muffin from a store now that I know I can make them just as good or even better than what you can find at a cafe for $2!  I have been freezing mashed ripe bananas for a couple weeks now, and finally decided to make some banana bread. I decided muffins would be easier to handle for reheating, etc., and decided this recipe sounded great. I made only a few minor changes to the recipe as written:  - added 1/8 tsp. of ground cinnamon - added a dash of ground nutmeg - substituted 1/8 cup of Splenda brown sugar blend for 1/4 cup of the sugar - added a few chopped almonds to the mix and a few sliced almonds to the top for crunch and presentation  I'd say the changes were great. I especially love the sliced almonds on top! So yummy.... I will definitely make these again.

text:
AMAZING RECIPE! Made as written + 1 TB cinnamon, 1/2 tsp nutmeg, 1/2 tsp allspice, 1/8 tsp cardamom. Also, I did not melt the butter (used softened butter at room temp). I used 4 medium bananas instead of 3 large bananas, and the banana flavor REALLY popped. Muffins were puffy, gorgeous, and delicious. Highly recommend. Side note, my muffins (full-sized, not mini) only took 17 minutes to bake ... my oven temp is probably off, but keep an eye on these because they might be ready sooner than you think.

text:
a great recipe!!  The results from my high school students were amazing!  We tested a few of the reviewers comments: added 1/4 teaspoon of cinnamon-these were more tasty but less of a banana flavor; using stand mixer to mix instead of by hand turned out more dry and didn't rise as much; adding nuts gave it more texture; 1/8 t cinnamon & 1/8 t nutmeg & walnuts  and stirring was the favorite of the class-more flavor, texture, but still a great banana flavor.

text:
These are great muffins. I used whole wheat flour and 1/4 cup splenda brown sugar mix. Added some vanilla and cinamon. Also dumped some left over blueberries in. also some crushed pecans.

They were very light and fluffy.. Made the small muffins. 24 to a tin.

text:
Nice! I halved the recipe since there are only two of us but used 2 medium bananas than the 2 1/2 stated, I also added 1/2 tsp vanilla extract and 1/4tsp cinnamon, obviously would be double if I made the whole recipe.
I used a small muffin tin and it yielded 9. They are very nice and very basic. 
I had 2 ripe bananas and thought I should use them up so looked for a very basic recipe and found this one! Next time I'd add some chocolate chips or some nuts and maybe have a streusel topping since these aren't very sweet.
Overall a good recipe and great with a cup of coffee or tea. :)

text:
Super Yummy Muffins – So Moist. I’ve made these several times now and they are just the best. We substituted the nuts with chocolate chips and added the 1 tsp of vanilla, 1 tsp cinnamon and ¼ tsp of nutmeg. For fluffy muffins, only mix the wet and dry ingredients until combined - moistened, don’t over stir or mix with a mixer. These have come out divine every time. This is now my go to recipe for banana muffins.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent and easy! I make these often. My method is to let the dry ingredients sit while I blend bananas, sugar, egg, and butter with a hand-held mixer. Once this is really smooth, I add a fourth banana broken into small chunks because I like having bits of banana I can taste. I also top the muffins with a streusel mixture before baking (1/2 C. white sugar, 1/3 C. flour, 1 1/2 t. cinnamon, 1/4 C. butter---cut to resemble coarse crumbs). I always use overripe bananas since they're softer and their flavour is more pervasive, and when I mix the wet and dry ingredients, I stir only until they're just barely combined. They come out fluffy and soft and very banana-y every time.

text:
These muffins are more cake like in texture and not "heavy" as banana muffins & breads usually are.  I substituted a heaping TBSP of sour cream in place of the egg, I do not eat eggs and they turned out every bit as good. Once the ingredients (sp?) are combined, quickly place them in the muffin tins/cups, and get them in the over.  This is one of our more favourite recipes.  Easy to make and once made are quickly consumed.  Thank You for sharing this.

Yummy! These muffins are a mild banana muffin alternative for those who aren't crazy about BIG banana taste, but need to use up old bananas - great for "smushy banana" haters like my four-year old! ;o)  Very good.  Not sure where the "healthy" part of these muffins comes in, besides the banana.  There seems to be a lot of sugar, and no whole grain stuff.  The only advantage is the small amount of butter.... so I substituted 1c. w/w flour for white.  These are great topped with a few choc. chips for a special treat.  Thanks for the recipe! These will become a fav in our house, especially for after-school snacks.

Display Name:
JayDubya

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/196453.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a fantastic recipe, but of course I made a few adjustments: I used 1 C white flour + 1/2 C wheat flour, split the sugar into part white sugar + part packed brown sugar, and instead of butter I used almost entirely unsweetened applesauce and topped it off with about 1 TBS of Enova oil.  To the batter I also added about 3/4 C of raisins, and about 1 TBS of cinnamon and 1 tsp of vanilla extract.  Once muffin tins were filled, I sprinkled a few more raisins on top, along with toasted coconut for a little crunch.  Baked for 30 minutes.  They were DELICIOUS (and perhaps a little healthier, too!)  One last note: I was taught that using an electric mixer with muffin batter is a no-no because it overblends the batter and makes it too chewy or rubbery.  All you need is a sturdy spatula to mix everything just until evenly moistened.  Just be sure your wet ingredients are well-blended first.  Perfect!

text:
For noobs (like myself), this is an awesomely simple but beautiful recipe!  I wanted to make the bakery styled exploding top muffins.  So I preheated the oven to 425, coated the pan with lots of non-stick spray.  Then, I just followed directions.  Beat the wet stuff in on high, and hand stir the dry stuff until mixture is lumpy.  (I snuck in some chocolate chips and almond slices here... not so healthy anymore... >.

userID:
22952742
Display Name:
Dori
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the first time I feel compelled to review a recipe, but these muffins are just so SUPER quick and EASY, and come out tasty. Would be great to bake with kids, too. 
I buy discounted bananas and stick them in the freezer, then microwave when needed, cut off the tip and squeeze out like toothpaste. I add all the dry ingredients together and use a whip to blend together, then I add in whatever I have on hand, like shredded coconut, walnuts, almonds, cranberries, cut up apricots etc -. and then, ever so gently, fold in the wet ingredients. I also double up the recipe, and use just a bit less sugar and baking soda (I find the baking soda can be tasted just a bit otherwise), and like others also added in vanilla.  I also use a little less butter, and I have in the past made these with all apple sauce or mix of banana and apple sauce as well.  It makes 6 great sized muffin heads plus 6 regular sized muffins for me with a double recipe. An absolute winner, would be a perfect recipe to make with kids as so versatile, you could add chocolate chips I would guess, or you could put all kinds of extra ingredients in a bowl and let them make their own type muffins.

text:
I've made these muffins every single week since I found this recipe, we love them!! The only changes I made (after making it exactly as written the first time) are to use only 1/2 cup brown sugar, unsweetened apple sauce in place of the melted butter, and I added 1 tsp of vanilla extract. These changes absolutely are not needed as the original recipe is awesome!! I only made the changes to make them a little healthier and the vanilla just adds a little more to the flavor for me. This recipe also makes exactly 12 muffins for us. I recommend this recipe to everyone I know that likes banana muffins!

Delicious easy recipe and of course I put my own spin on it.  Added a shake of cinnamon to the dry ingredients.  Also threw a few handfuls of chocolate chips to the flour mixture. Flour keeps them from sinking to the bottom. To the wet ingredients I added a teaspoon of vanilla and a 1/4 cup of chunky applesauce.  I topped with chopped walnuts after the batter was scooped into the tin. Bake time was 25 minutes and I only got 11 muffins out of this recipe.  Very moist and tasty!

They looked absolutely beautiful and were nice, moist and light, not dense. Will make again. TY

Follow your nose and start checking when the banana muffin smell starts to make you crazy and draws your stomach to the kitchen.

text:
Great recipe.  
I made it gluten free by substituting for the flour:
1/2 C.ground almonds
1/2 C. tapioca starch
1/2 C potato starch (corn starch or rice flour isn't kosher for Passover)
I used oil instead of butter to make it dairy free
My husband loved it.

brown sugar instead of white
vanilla extract
cinnamon and nutmeg
1t. salt 
I throw all the wet ingredients together + salt, cinnamon and nutmeg (dissolves better)- electric mixer
fold in flour and rising agents
then into the oven- super easy.

text:
These muffins are simple to make, and are quite moist.  I used a mixture of whole wheat and white flour for a cup of the flour, and substituted a 1/2-cup of wheat germ for the last 1/2-cup of flour.  This may have caused them to be a bit crumbly, but they are nonetheless quite tasty.

My daughter, an avid banana avoider, finally relented and tasted one, then proceeded to eat several in a row.  

Definitely a hit at our house!

text:
YUMM!! Made this exactly as written and we loved how these came out - great texture, flavor, and moistness. You could probably easily replace the butter with applesauce, and reduce the sugar a little (if using very overripe bananas like I did) - but really these don't need to be changed at all. We all really enjoyed these, and the leftovers were great the next day for a quick breakfast snack.

I've been making these muffins for years, the recipe is perfect as written, no need to change a thing. I now make them in a single bowl, first combining the wet ingredients, then stirring in baking powder, baking soda and salt, finally folding in the flour. So much easier and the results are identical, always moist and light.

Easy and quick! Follow the recipe as written and it won't fail.

text:
I decided to make this because I was fairly certain that I had all of the ingredients. The result? A dozen very very delicious banana muffins. The taste had that banana flavor, but not overpowering. The reason for the four stars is that this muffin needed a little bit more of actual sweetness (if my mom or my brother, my brother being extremely picky with food, was writing this review, they would give five stars)... and it looked a bit like a bran muffin (although that isn't exactly the reason I docked points). It's very very easy as well - I WAS intending to do it on my own when my mother arrived, but oh well. A big hit with the family - six were quickly snatched away within seconds of popping out of the oven, with them smelling like typical banana and looking like typical banana. We're intending to make it this Thanksgiving; hopefully we'll double or maybe triple the recipe! I also changed the recipe from all-purpose flour to Sofasilk's cake flour, but I doubt that it made a difference.

These were simple and great tasting. I wanted a simple recipe and this was it! I had to make 1/3 batch because I only had 1 super ripe banana (who has 3 at a time, anyway??), so since you can't add 1/3 of an egg, I used 1/3 of a "flaxseed egg" (1 tsp ground flaxseed, 3 tsp water, mix & let sit 2 minutes-it didn't have a great texture but I put it in anyway and it worked great!). I didn't add anything to this recipe and I made 4 large muffins, which cooked for about 20 minutes and were very tasty :)

text:
Absoloutely wonderful.  I followed the recipe exactly, and when puttining it on the cupcake liners, I topped it with walnuts. I made it for breakfast and the smell was overwhelming! I put it in the oven for 25 minutes-it made it really brown, like on the verge of burning but it was still good. The recipe is fabulous for making something delicious with bannanas. But adding nuts should be a must! I don't think it would be as good without a little crunch to it. Definetely making these again. Can't resist seconds or thirds!

text:
Very good!  I used all whole wheat pastry flour instead of all-purpose, melted shortening instead of butter (we were out), and substituted 1/4 cup of white sugar with brown.  I also added 1 tsp each of vanilla and cinnamon, 1/4 tsp of pumpkin spice, 1/8 tsp allspice, and a dash of nutmeg.  They look and taste great!  Husband loves them too- good way to use up aging bananas!

text:
I loved these! I doubled the recipe and used half wheat, half white flour. I used Xagave instead of sugar, and added cinnamon, and nutmeg. I forgot to add the eggs and didn't realize it until we had all tucked into them. We love them anyway! Couldn't notice. Since the bananas are an emulsifier, it didn't need it. The only con is I thought they were too salty. I could taste salt. It wasn't overpowering, but definately noticable. Next time, I'll reduce the salt by half. This recipe is a keeper.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I realized I had forgotten to add butter when I was already scooping them into the muffin cups but by then it was too late! However, this recipe doesn't even need butter. The muffins turned out PERFECTLY. They were slightly crispy, rose beautifully and tasted heavenly. I used half wheat flour have regular flour and added the cinnamon, nutmeg, and vanilla as recommended by others. Then, I used my mixer to blend the bananas, egg, sugar, and vanilla after mashing the bananas by hand. I folded in the dry ingredients as the recipe called for and used an icecream scoop to put portioned amounts in the cups. Removing the butter took away about 300 total calories. Don't tell my husband the muffins are good for him ;D

text:
I just made these and they are soooo YUMMY!  I did make a few substitutions because I was making them for my diabetic mom and 22 month old son (neither of whom need any extra sugar in their system!)  I used 1c whole wheat flour + 1/2c white flour, substituted the white sugar wiith 1/2c of organic blue agave sweetener, and used unsweetened applesauce instead of butter then baked as directed!    They came out perfect!  Definitely will be making these again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So I had a few brown bananas but was missing the sour cream that my normal banana bread recipe calls for. I decided it was time to branch out. After reading other reviews I decided to change the sugar to 1/2 c. white sugar and 1/4 c. brown sugar. I had also intended on adding a splash vanilla but completely forgot. I made some muffins with walnuts, some with chocolate chips and some plain. I definitely enjoyed the ones with nuts the most. These are very very moist muffins (I'm sure due to the fact that there are 3 bananas!) but I found then took a lot longer to bake. My mini muffins too almost 20 minutes and my regular muffins took almost 30. Will definitely make again in lieu of my sour cream recipe.

country:

text:
These deserve a five star- but I make several additions/substitutions to try to make them healthier and, I think, tastier.  I've made this recipe several times and they always come out great!  If you're trying to banana nut bread use a loaf pan, well greased and bake for at least an hour (I made the mistake last time of not letting it cook long enough :-( ).  Anyway, here are my regular substitutions:  1 tsp cinnamon to the flour mixture, 1 tsp of vanilla to the banana mixture, chopped walnuts to the banana mixture BEFORE adding dry mix, 1 c whole wheat flour instead of 1 c of the all-purpose.  This time I tried using less of the melted butter and supplementing with plain- no sugar added applesauce- enough to bring the volume up to 1/3 c total.  And I tried some streussel topping, but I think it may have failed.

text:
These muffins are AMAZING!  I added 1 tsp of vanilla as others suggested.  To make it even easier I used the food processor.  First process bananas to a smooth puree, then add sugar and egg (and vanilla if desired) and process again.  Add melted butter or oil through the tube with the motor running.  Add baking powder, baking soda and salt and process again.  Then add flour and pulse a few times to combine, don't overprocess.  I made 6 jumbo muffins and they were done in about 40 minutes to perfection!

Good muffins!  I added 1/2 tsp of cinnamon and 1/4 tsp of nutmeg and a teaspoon of vanilla like other reviewers, cut the amount of butter and used 1/4 c of applesauce instead for lower fat muffins like another user suggested.  Didn't have any brown sugar or I would have used part brown sugar instead of all granulated sugar.. but I added a little bit of molasses (a little less than 1/8 cup) and that made these really good!  Guess I changed a lot, but they turned out awesome.  Added some chocolate chips and made mini muffins, and my husband and toddler loved them!  It was a good way to get my son to eat some bananas.

text:
Quite a nice recipe - did change a bit to our tastes, used applesauce to replace most of the melted butter (made the applesauce at home using the 'sarah's applesauce' recipe); and the peels left over from the apples were cut up coarsely and added to the muffin mix for a bit of texture variation and added fibre/nutrients.  Also added a bit of vanilla and cinnamon.  Adding a crumb/oatmeal topping also enhances the flavour a bit.  So; as written; 4 stars; with the changes; 5...  Thanks for the recipe!

Exceptionally moist, light and tasty muffins! I only had 2 large ripe bananas and still they tasted awesome. They only thing I did different was to add vanilla. I don't know if anyone noticed, but this is the exact same recipe as the banana crumb muffin from this site, but without the crumb topping. Anyway, I made this one with half ww flour, and one of the 3 bananas was a frozen banana, that I melted along with the butter. I don't know if this had anything to do with how good it came out, but the texture of these muffins was unbelievably moist, and bakery quality (Even better!). My kids my friend, my husband and I were unanimous on how delicious and great texture these were! Thanks so much for this great recipe.

text:
Fantastic! Very quick and easy to make, and they stay very moist even a couple days later! ... i add a crumble topping to mine: 1/4C brown sugar, 1/6C all-purpose flour, 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1 TBS melted butter, mix with a fork and then with your hands a bit if it's too clumpy. sprinkle on the tops before you put it in the oven. Yum!

VERY good! I added 1 tsp. vanilla, as others suggested and also a little bit of water (maybe 1/4 c.?) to ensure they would be moist (most muffins I make from scratch tend to turn out dry).  Next time though, I plan on using Canola oil instead of butter, to make them more healthy. Also, will add a little bit of honey. Nice alternative to banana bread.

These were delicious! I followed this recipe this the exception of using 4 medium bananas (as opposed to 3 large) and substituted 1/4 cup brown sugar for some of the white sugar (1/2 cup white,1/4 cup brown).  I checked on the muffins after about 22 minutes.  I really enjoyed how they weren't high in fat or calories, too.  My husband tried them before I did and he loved them!  Thanks for the recipe :-)  Enjoy!

userID:
2175607
Display Name:
ebiddlec

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I enjoyed this recipe a lot!  I did make a lot of substitutions, in attempt to make it as healthy as possible - it still ended up being very tasty!  Here are the changes I made: For the flour I substituted 1 cup whole wheat flour and 0.5 cup all purpose flour.  I ended up using 4 (fairly large) bananas.  For the sugar, I used 0.5 cup splenda and  0.25 cup (maybe a little less) brown sugar.  For the butter, I used 0.5 cup unsweetened applesauce.  I also added 1 teaspoon of cinnamon and 0.5 teaspoon nutmeg.  I would have added vanilla extract, but I was out.  This made 12 largish muffins.  Once cool, I 'iced' each with some fat free vanilla yogurt, and sprinkled them with toasted walnuts and toasted shredded coconut.

text:
DELICIOUS!!! Whole fam loves them! The first time, I followed directions exactly - 2nd time I used 2.5T butter & 2.5T applesauce instead of all butter to cut down on fat. Worked great. They freeze really well - when you want to use them, let them thaw for 10 min. or so, then wrap in foil and put in 350degree oven for 15 min.  I used the convection function on my oven and baked them at 325 degrees for 18 min. We'll be making this recipe often!

text:
Verrrry light and moist! These are wonderful! I might just use this as my main banana bread (loaf) recipe! One reviewer stated these are not as dense as they would like; personally, I LOVE the light and fluffy texture! I made them AS IS. No additions or substitutions. The recipe made exactly 24 mini muffins. I don't know how someone got 48?! Perhaps because I fill my mini's to the top of the tin? They *do* bake a bit longer than the specified 10 minutes ~ I went about 13 and that was perfect! Again, could be because I filled them to the top! A keeper for sure! Thanks for sharing!

Wonderful recipe! I've made these a bunch of times and every time they come out great!
A few tips...
-use over ripe bananas- the riper, the better
- stir the wet and dry ingredients as little as possible, just till combined - stirring too much makes the muffins dry and tough

These are delicious.  The batter is just the right amount to fill 12 baking cups, if you fill them to the top.  I am used to filling a baking cup only 2/3 full, so I was skeptical about filling them so full.  I was pleasantly surprised when they came out perfectly.  They are flatter than other muffins, but they are moist and super tasty.  Another thing I should mention, mine were very done in 20 minutes.  It could be my oven, but others may want to check sooner than the 25-30 mins.

These are the best banana muffins!  I add 1 tsp. vanilla and only put about half of the butter and added 3 spoonfuls of sour cream.  They were so moist and yummy, it gives you exactly 12 muffins without wasting any batter.  My kids loved them!  By the way for the people who said they didn't have a lot of banana flavor, you have to let them get really ripe and they will have a ton of flavor.

text:
Wonderfully kid friendly recipe!  It takes good old fashioned elbow grease to mash the bananas, which my boys LOVE.  
I found that if we use room temp butter and mash it with the sugar, bananas and egg, the muffins come out with a much more pleasant texture.  Further, I used 1 full cup of sugar, followed the 1tsp cinnamon and 1/4tsp nutmeg advice omitting the vanilla.  
In the words of my percosious 4 year old:  "MMMM they're very banana-eee!"

text:
I got halfway through the baking time on these muffins before I realized that I had not added the sugar.  It was a hectic morning and I had been trying to get these done for breakfast.  I thought they were going to be horrible w/o the sugar, but luckily I had added 1/3 cup of mini chocolate chips.  And, they were actually quite good.  The ripe bananas and the chocolate chips sweetened it enough.  Next time, if I have my head on straight, I think I will add some sugar (maybe 1/4 cup.)  They were very good and super easy to make.  It also appeared that there was too much dry mixture, but I mixed until it was just all wet and they baked up light and fluffy.

Delicious. After reading the reviews I made the following changes:
substituted 1/2 C of the flour with oats, used 1/3 C white sugar and 1/4 brown (could probably even use less) and added a teaspoon of vanilla. i also add chocolate or carob chips, but they are so good on their own they really don't need it. also, i don't use an electric mixer. i like the consistency of the muffin when i stir the ingredients by hand.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an excellent muffin.  Made them this morning for breakfast with the kids and grandkids, and they were still warm when they came over.  Made 12.  The only things I can say about this recipe is to use Pam for Baking when you are spraying the muffin tins and they come right out.  Also, I didn't beat until smooth after I added the flour - I just beat until the dry stuff was incorporated.  I've found that beating until smooth leaves big holes in the muffins.  I will use this recipe for banana muffins forevermore.  Thanks!!!

text:
This is the second time I am reviewing this recipe, because today I goofed and the recipe turned out even better than usual.  It was the end of the day and I was pooped and I didn't feel like melting the butter so I used the same amount of vegetable oil.  They turned out great.  And they were a little more moist than usual.  I use this same recipe to make really great pumpkin muffins, too.  I just replace the banana with pumpkin.  I triple the recipe and use a large can of pumpkin puree.  But for a single batch, I would probably use about a cup and a half.  I topped them with a simple crumb topping.  (I used the topping from the Blueberry muffins To Die For from this site.)  The pumpkin are the current favorite muffin at the shop.

city:

text:
These were delish.  I used 3 good sized bananas from my freezer (does anyone else do this?  I always end up with one really over-ripe banana from my bunch so I toss it in my banana-bag in the freezer.  They're perfect for making banana breads with- just thaw a few out, and slip them out of their skins! Warning though, they WILL turn black, but don't let it worry you!).  I think I could have used another one and it wouldn't have hurt.  I also threw in about a cup of fresh blueberries since I had a bunch to use up and that was yummy but they would have been just fine without! Just like little wee banana loaf but without the hour + in the oven.  This is my new banana breakfast treat!

text:
I made two variations of this recipe and they were both excellent.  The first batch the only changes I made was to add 1 tsp. of vanilla and it only took 19 mins to cook.  The second batch (for my kids) I substituted oatmeal for 1/2 of the flour, substituted brown sugar for half the white sugar, added a cup of raisins, 1 tsp. of vanilla, 1 tsp. of cinnamin.  Both great recipes, just the right amount of banana and not too sweet.  Hope you enjoy!!!

Just updating my review, I wanted to thank "Abi" for sharing this delicious recipe.  I have been making these muffins for almost 2 years now, at least once a month (I always seem to have some over ripe bananas left over)  They are soooo good, and simple to make, 5 minutes to stir up and then into the oven, so easy.  My little guy who is 4 has literally grown up on these and loves helping me make them (and eat them)!  Sometimes I drizzle some of the leftover melted butter over the muffins and sprinkle with brown sugar before I put them in the oven. MMMM!!!!  So, thank you Abi, I no longer need to refer to the recipe, as I have made them so often!

country:
None
text:
This is a 5 star recipe!  I usually don't like reviews (especially bad reviews) of recipes that have been changed significantly, however in this case it turned out WONDERFULLY and I truly believe it's because the core recipe was wonderful.  I substituted half of the all-purpose flour for whole wheat flour and I "sprinkled" chocolate chips and peanut butter chips on top (to make it more kids friendly, however it probably didn't need it, as well as these turned out).  My four children absolutely loved them.  I sifted the flours twice to ensure they were mixed well with the baking soda/powder and salt. It only took 18 minutes to cook but I divided them into 17 muffins.  I read one review that said they didn't rise well...I think they should check the freshness of their soda/powder, as I didn't have ANY problems with them rising.  A quick easy, and inexpensive breakfast!!!  Thank you for sharing!!!

text:
I just made these muffins.  Although they were very good, light, moist and spongy, they didn't seem to rise very much at all.  I suggest you make maybe 6-8 muffins, and fill the batter right to the top of the muffin tin or past.  I added some vanilla and a little splash of milk, and turn my oven down to 325 once I put them in.  Also, they would probably also be very good with some dried cranberries.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
THESE ARE AMAZING.  My family and I are in love with them. We have made these SO many times!  As written, these are so great, but we do add thigs, as many others have. I add 2 tsp cinnamon and 1/2 tsp nutmeg to the dry mix. I also add 2 tsp vanilla extract to the wet mix. After BARELY combining the wet and dry ingredients, I add 3/4 cup mini chocolate chips.,and fold in gently. DO NOT OVER-MIX the batter. Fill mini muffin/cupcake liners about 3/4 full. Makes 48 mini muffins.

This is a really simple and delicious banana bread recipe. I followed it as written except I added about 3/4 cup   chopped walnuts. Yum!  So good!  I used a silicone muffin pan and sprayed it with Pam. I baked for 20 minutes and they browned up nicely and were super moist and not a bit undercooked. If you are looking for a simple recipe with simple ingredients that you probably already have, this is a good one to try.

These are so good!  I used a scant measure of both the baking soda and  baking powder and used oil instead of butter.   I used three large bananas and substituted part of the white sugar with brown. text:
I think this recipe is a great starter point for banana bread. I added 1 tsp vanilla, 1 tsp cinnamon, 1/4 tsp nutmeg, 2 extra eggs, and 1/2 a cup of butter instead of the 1/3. I recommend whipping your egg whites to stiff peaks and folding them into the wet ingredients for a fluffier bread. Will be making again!

text:
These are hands down the BEST banana muffins I have ever made.  I followed other reviewers advice with the 1:2 tsp vanilla but also added a 1/2 tsp of pumpkin pie spice (cinnamon, clove and a couple other things).  I also headed the other reviewers advise not to over mix...just enough to get wet.  Mine ended up perfect golden brown with a slightly sweet crisp “muffin top”.  I love the author has made this a “basic” recipe so I can make them my own.

A seriously good recipe, a fave that I've made many times.

I'll add choc. chips, or nutmeg and cinnamon to it, depending on my mood.  And to shake things up a bit.  
I save some for the next day, in the fridge.  Otherwise, these muffins do disappear.

I add 1/3 cup of sugar to this, instead of 2/3.  Still a great recipe!

text:
I've made this recipe quite a few times and richly enjoyed it!
This time, I only had two banana and we were out of eggs, so I substituted both with applesauce. I also followed previous reviews and added 1 tsp cinnamon, 1/2 tsp nutmeg , a splash of vanilla and a splash of milk. I also added walnuts and chocolate chips! (I know, major deviations)
To my pleasant surprise, they turned out perfectly, and a little more moist than usual. Definitely a staple recipe for my muffins!

country:
None
text:
I made a gluten/egg free version! I used gluten free flour. I also substituted apple sauce for the egg. Then to spice things up a bit I added 1/2 small chopped apple, crushed walnuts along with vanilla extract, and pumpkin pie spice. I used 1/2 the sugar it called for but added some maple syrup instead. Topped them with a dash of cinnamon. I made these in mini muffins. I highly recommend using a silicone muffin pans! They pop right out without any battle and no need for paper inserts! (I also made large muffins and followed the recipe except for using gluten free flour and added some walnuts.) My whole family loved them both!

I made this recipe with these changes:
To make them healthier I used whole wheat flour
I used coconut sugar
In place of butter I used olive oil
And I added grounded walnuts grinder in the mini food processor 
Talk about delicious, healthy and filled with protein.
I doubled the batch and did half plain banana with the nuts and did sprinkle a bit of flour and sugar for the topping 
And the 2nd batch I did dark chocolate chips-healthier for a lil extra sweetness and antioxidants

None
text:
This is my go-to banana muffin recipe! Some have said theirs turn out dry. My solution for that is to measure your banana. Make sure however many you use, it equals 2 cups mashed. It actually took 4 for me with the size I had. I also sprinkle coarse sugar on top before baking to give them a little extra specialness. You can include a half to a whole cup walnut pieces if you like nuts in yours as well!

text:
Perfect recipe for tasty banana muffins. I tripled this recipe and it did not disappoint. Both mini muffins and regular size muffins were moist, solid, and devoured by all whom they were distributed to. 
There was a few hours pause between baking batches and the later were as good as the first. I believe that means they can be prepped ahead of time, the night before baking.
I made this recipe a second time, and didn't have enough butter. I replaced the butter with 1/2 as much unsweetened apple sauce, and used turbinado sugar. Still excellent!
10 out of 10, would definitely recommend.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my go-to when I end up with over-ripe bananas.  I've made it dozens of times.  A few variations I like to use:  replace half or all of the butter with unrefined coconut oil.  It adds a sweet, coconut flavor.  The last time I made it, I also replaced the sugar with 1/2 c agave nectar.  Still plenty sweet, but a much lower glycemic index (less of a sugar crash). If you substitute agave, it tends to brown faster so I lowered the heat by 25 degrees.  

I've also added fruit such as blueberries, nuts, or mini chocolate chips on occasion to add some variety.

Absolutely delicious!! I’ve made these a few times, and each time, they got better. I just added a cup of chopped almonds (you could use walnuts or pecans too) and half a teaspoon of cinnamon. I gifted these to a very sick teacher and got so many compliments!! Great potluck or breakfast recipe!!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6699269.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The original recipe was decent, but I found it was too sweet and too dense texture-wise, so I experimented somewhat. After many times tweaking the recipe, I found the best course of action is to add a tablespoon of cinnamon and a teaspoon of vanilla extract; multiply the amount of butter by 1.5x; remove the soda altogether, and cut the amount of baking powder and the amount of sugar in half; substitute a quarter of the white sugar with light brown sugar; and slightly reduce the amount of flour. This produces a tasty result with a nice, fluffy texture.

I Love this recipe, and we always double it because we are a large family. However, I did make some modifications! text:
Super yummy! I used 4 bananas which had been frozen so I left them out overnight to thaw completely. I also used only 1/2 cup of sugar, since my bananas were older and therefore sweeter. I'm glad I did because even with 1/2 cup of sugar, they were aaaalmost too sweet. I also added 1/2 cup walnuts and a handful or two of semi-sweet chocolate chips.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the complete recipe and made sure to mash the bananas a lot because I saw in a previous review the muffins turned out dry. I made sure to fold the dry and wet ingredients together just so there were no dry ingredients to be seen. This is a very basic recipe and I am 15 and was able to make this.  The batter had a medium level of banana flavor. I filled the muffin tins 3/4 of the way full. The muffins taste very well and I would give the taste five stars. The texture is pretty dry but they are still an enjoyable 3 stars. The top turned out crunchy. I made the larger ones.
Tip: only leave the larger muffins in for 20 min, or even less.

text:
I've made this recipe a few times now, as it is written, not changing a thing, and that is why I've rated the recipe 5 stars.  I must say it is perfect the way it is!  I also must say that I was shocked to see so many reviewers rate it 5 and then go on to say they added vanilla and cinnamon to the recipe.  This is a banana muffin recipe and that's why you DON'T add vanilla and cinnamon.  You want to taste the bananas in a banana muffin recipe.  If you wanted a spice muffin or cinnamon muffin, then you shouldn't  be rating this recipe and then telling about all the changes you made to it.  You're supposed to rate the recipe here; not your changes to it.  Change any recipe any way you like but don't rate the original recipe as you didn't make it.

None
text:
I have been eating these muffins almost everyday for breakfast for years now, so I figured I should probably finally take the time to review them. I love this recipe as it is written, but it's also super versatile and I have changed it up many times and have never had a flop. I have subbed honey for the sugar, added wheat germ/flax seed, subbed applesauce for butter, used whole wheat flour, even made them gluten free for a family member, the list of changes could go on for a long time. And every single time they turn out great! Seriously, if you're looking for a great banana muffin recipe stop here. Make it as it's written, fall in love with it, then start tweaking it. You will not regret it!

text:
I make 6 jumbo muffins with this recipe & use vegetable oil instead of butter. Fold in 1/2 c walnuts & sprinkle some on top. Bake at exactly 350°F for 30 minutes. Cool a couple minutes in the pan then remove & finish cooling on a rack. I store them in a big tupperware airtight container after COMPLETELY COOL. Next day they are moist & chewy on top. Absolutely delicious for breakfast & with coffee.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A few tweaks to this recipe yielded the best muffins I've ever made.
My bananas were a bit small which made the batter a bit dry and thick. 
To add moisture I added one additional banana, 1/2 teaspoon of vanilla extract and about 2 tablespoons of Kahlua. This  made the batter the appropriate consistency. 
And because we like nuts and chocolate I added about a cup of chocolate chips and fat fistfull of chopped walnuts.
Bake time was right at 25 minutes. 
Best.Muffin.Ever.

I pulled mine out at 16 minutes and they were still slightly overdone.  The finished product is also rather heavy, and I can taste the leavening.  There are better banana muffin recipes out there.  I’ll keep looking.

The first few times I made these I noticed the temp & time was odd for muffins (muffins typically bake @ 400) but went with it anyway &  they burnt every time, especially on the bottom. This morning I adjusted temp to 400° and baked for 15 min and they turned out absolutely perfect! I always add 2 TBS of ground flax seed to make them a bit healthier.

userID:
10434351
Display Name:
Linda Kauffer
isPro:

4

2

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1930646.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have used this recipe for ten years. I freeze bananas that don't get eaten, and several times a year use them in this recipe to make muffins (regular-sized and large),  or mini and mid-sized  loaves, and even a whole loaf-adjusting bake times accordingly. I have added chopped dried cherries, dried cranberries, candied pineapple, raisins, golden raisins (lol, only one item per batch, I don't want to remind anyone of fruitcake!), and ALWAYS a cup of chopped walnuts or pecans. I have sometimes substituted the applesauce. I have made them with and without a streusel topping. I only use bananas that have well ripened (just a skosh  before too ripe), and I use four instead of three. I sometimes also add the vanilla and cinnamon. This recipes does well doubled, and the muffins/loaves freeze well.  I give mini loaves to the village workers who pick up trash, the mail carrier, and to my neighbors every Christmas. I have never been disappointed with this recipe. (Using riper bananas gives it a darker color).
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-12-14T02:52:28.367

text:
These are so easy to make and delicious! I made sure to not over mix and used an ice cream scoop to get the batter into the pan. Mine made 11 normal sized muffins. I added 1 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1/4 tsp nutmeg, and a tsp of vanilla extract, roughly. If you like banana bread but want something easier to take on the go, these are awesome. Highly recommend and will make again, for sure!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was amazing and I've made it multiple times- and I have made multiple changes to the recipe.
The ingredients that I used were(I made a double batch):
1 cup whole wheat flour
2 cups all purpose flour
2 tsp baking soda
2 tsp baking powder
1 cup brown sugar
1/4 cup granulated white sugar
8 ripe bananas
2 eggs
1/2 cup applesauce
1/3 cup melted butter
cinnamon
vanilla extract
I baked the 24 muffins for exactly 25 minutes and they were moist and light.  They even tasted great after being  re-heated in the microwave the next day.

I had four large bananas that I needed to use up so I added 1 cup of brown sugar instead of white sugar, 2 eggs, 2 1/4 cups of flour, 1 1/2 teaspoons of powder and soda, 2/3rd cup melted butter, 1/4 of sour cream for moisture, and a teaspoon vanilla. I didn’t want to over mix as others have stated.

text:
Great banana muffins! Made this recipe as listed except I added 1/3 c buttermilk. Be sure to mix all dry ingredients first and then add all the wet items, including the bananas last. Don’t stir until all wet ingredients are in the bowl. Then stir gently and as little as possible.

Followed the recipe exactly and was happy with the results! I didn't read the reviews before I started, so I mixed the batter quite thoroughly. Although many comments recommended mixing the batter conservatively, the muffins still turned out moist while also keeping their fluff! I actually prefer muffins to be less oily and sweet, so in a future batch I would cut down a bit on the butter and the sugar. A great way to save overripe bananas!

text:
Made them gluten free using the King Arthur GF 1 to 1 flour. Turned out great! I’ve made these a half dozen times now with no complaints. Because I’m GF, I let them cool, wrap each one in plastic wrap and freeze them. To reheat, I nuke one in the microwave for 15-20 seconds, then put it in the toaster oven on bake at 375 degrees for 7-10 minutes. It tastes freshly made, the outside is crispy and inside moist and soft.

userID:
15735909
Display Name:
Kay
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2263039.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had some bananas that were overripe and no one was going to eat, so I googled for banana recipes that were quick and used what I had in hand and found this recipe. Since the bananas were overripe that means they were very sweet by themselves, so I used 1/3 instead of 3/4 cup of sugar. I also used brown sugar instead of white. The batter was a bit thick so you may I want to add a little milk or water to thin it out a bit, if you want...I didn’t. The recipe says this would yield 12 servings but I got 8, but that may be because I used an ice cream scooper instead of a spoon to add batter to the tin. The muffins turned out just right. I’m glad I added less sugar because they had the right amount of sweetness.

text:
Ive been a chef/baker for 50 years and i must say this recipe is excellent . I personally think people who dont like this are missing the traditional cinnamon,nutmeg ect that they are used to. The consistency  is perfect as is the lightness Dont mix the batter smooth as u will get a heavier product Just mix with a fork  until ingredients are wet I buy bannanas leave them out till they start turning black put them in the freezer to use at a later date , peel them while still frozen bymaking a simple cut lengthwise...so simple and flavorful. enjoy! my family and i are!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe consistently makes excellent, moist muffins as is, so long as you are mindful not to overmix your wet and dry combo. When I started making them with my daughter, we started adding cinnamon, vanilla and chocolate chips, all which she adds in quite liberally because you can't go wrong with any amount of these 3 ingredients-- you can't--and pour it into a loaf pan to make a bread. Mana from heaven! Additionally, if we have a fourth banana, we'll throw it in and  it's that much better! But it's consistently moist and tender. We usually don't cut into it until the next day so the flavors have had time to live with each other and socialize in a most delicious way. Trust, yo! It's worth waiting for the second day so plan ahead. So this is our go-to recipe for muffins or bread.

Very good recipe and I like that it uses butter instead of oil. My only additions and changes were brown sugar instead of granulated, 2 tsp vanilla, and 1/2 tbsp cinnamon. text:
Delicious recipe for moist, flavorful muffins! I did make just a few tweaks: 
1) halved the sugar, it was plenty sweet for us
2) added a splash of vanilla and a few sprinkles of cinnamon
3) added about 1c chopped walnuts
Agree with other reviewers that you want to mix only until the wet and dry ingredients are barely combined and you still see flecks of dry flour. The muffins I made must have been smaller because they were done after 22 min in the oven. These were so light and tasty fresh out of the oven, with a smear of Kerrygold butter omnomnom.

text:
I have been baking banana and banana nut muffins for over 50 years.  No recipe has ever come out this perfect.  I did add the vanilla, nutmeg, cinnamon and walnuts that others suggested.  Then I got creative.  I didn't have any mini-chocolate chips but I did have some chocolate covered raisins.  There was plenty of batter left after I filled up the 24 mini-muffin tin (enough for 6 regular sized muffins) so I added the chocolate covered raisins.  It was a fun treat.  The chocolate just melted perfectly and the raisins added to the muffin as well.  The batches baked in the time suggested in the recipe.  Others have mentioned they bake too quickly but I would start with the recommended time and watch them towards the end of the baking as there can be a variance in temperatures between ovens.

text:
They are good standard muffins--moist but not greasy or sticky. I added some freshly ground cinnamon and nutmeg. Sprinkling sugar on top of each before baking would add a crunchy glaze. Not to be too technical, but the word 'fold' has a specific meaning,  to gently add something like whipped egg whites to a batter with a spatula to retain as much air as possible, as in preparing a souffle. Also, mixing all the ingredients until smooth is an exercise in futility and unnecessary since you are working with mashed bananas.

I love when I make a mistake and it turns out.  I made the batter before I prepared the pan.  My muffin tin was no where to be found.  I ended up putting it in a 8" square dark-coated pan, dropped the oven to 325 and checked it at 25 minutes, gave it about 9 more minutes and toothpick came out clean.
It came out terrific!  Not muffins but it works well as a cake too!

So instead of butter I used 1/4 cup leftover  baby food (pear corn zucchini) and 1/3 cup coconut oil. Inspired by other reviewers I substituted some brown sugar and added vanilla nutmeg cinnamon walnuts chia seeds flax seeds and 1/4 chocolate chips. I will use this recipe again as it helped and held up to my notorious finagling. Very moist and tasty but oily...will reduce coconut oil next time..My batch yielded one dozen large muffins in parchment paper liners. Next time I will save the liners as the coconut oil should do the job.

These came out delicious! I did however make a couple tweaks 1. Cut sugar down to 1/2 c and that was still quite sweet and 2. Gently folded the batter just enough to incorporate everything being careful not to over mix. The end result was non dense and non soggy muffins!! Just for taste I did add 1t of vanilla, 1t of cinnamon and mini chocolate chips to half the batch.

text:
I did alter this recipe to make it more healthier. I used 1/2 cup whole wheat flour, used unsweetened apple sauce in place of butter, and used brown sugar (only 1/2 cup). I also added some vanilla (a big splash) and some cinnamon and nutmeg. Mine cooked up in 23 minutes and I got 11 muffins from my batter. My 3 year old really enjoyed it . I love making muffins with kids, they are so easy to through together. This is a great recipe that can easily be altered to make healthier, and they still stayed soft and fluffy.

text:
Good basic banana muffin. I added a tsp of vanilla,  tsp of cinnamon, and a 1/4 tsp of nutmeg. Also, 1/2-3/4 c of chocolate chips would be a yummy addition to this recipe. I prefer a 1/4 cup each of  whole wheat and bread flour in place of a 1/2 cup of all purpose. Next time I think I'll do half brown sugar and half white granulated sugar. Brown sugar is always a good way to bring out the banana flavor. I like to tinker, but I would definitely make these again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
in my house banana bread/muffins usually consist of whatever I have on hand.  I do add 3 mashed bananas but then I've been substituting mashed up pears (2) for sugar, a handful of old fashioned oats just for texture and substance, 1/2 reg flour and 1/2 whole wheat flour, and coconut oil for butter. The liquid from the pears is enough to balance the extra oats. As long as you stick to the basic essentials, (flour, egg, sugar, banana, baking powder/soda) you can add or substitute in so many ways.  I wind up checking on the muffins at 17 minute. sometimes they're ready, sometimes they need a few more minutes. We prefer them a bit underdone. Cooked thoroughly but on the moist side. Great recipe!!

text:
I rarely leave reviews as they are always filled with tweaks to the original recipe anyway, but... sometimes one must leave credit where it is due.  These were excellent in flavour and crumb.  They were also simple to make.  The key with any muffins, is to just "barely" mix the dry portion, with the wet.  Lumps, or even some stray powdery bits are what you "want" to see.  If you follow that simple secret for muffins, they will always be light and tender.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my go-to recipe for the best banana muffins ever.  I originally got it from Food.com (I think, but I wrote it out on a recipe card, which is now all marked up).
This is a great basic recipe for all kinds of substitutions.  Sometimes I use 1/2 cup honey instead of sugar (and I almost always cut down the sugar by 1/2, anyway esp. if I am adding cocoa or chocolate chips (I usually add 1/2c-1c, depending on how I feel).  Whenever I am out of eggs, or if I just feel like it, I have substituted 1T ground flax seed + 2T-3T water (I have also added 1c flax seed meal +2T-3T milk or water to the recipe which gives a nice nutty flavour). For extra chocolatey goodness I have added 1/4c cocoa powder.  Using this recipe as my base, I have NEVER had a problem with any of my substitutions or additions; only with omissions, like forgetting the baking power, soda and salt...dense (me and the muffins)!

text:
Great, easy recipe! As suggested by other users, I added 1 tsp vanilla, 1 tsp cinnamon, 1/4 tsp nutmeg, and 1/4 cup crushed walnuts. I also subbed out 1/4 cup of the flour for whole wheat (I may experiment pushing that a little higher and/or decreasing the sugar a bit). 

Tip: If you don't have a plastic pastry scraper, it's a very cheap tool that will speed up your mixing a lot.

Recipe made 12 standard-sized muffins that were done around 23 minutes.

userID:
6322251
Display Name:
Beth
isPro:

8

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/558475.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Simple, quick and oh my god good.  I made the recipe almost exact, subbing 1/2 cp wheat flour (personal preference).  I used kosher salt, which is slightly bigger in grains, therefore had a few places where I could taste the salt.  I would recommend using a little less salt if you're using salted butter.  Also, DO NOT beat these, do not mix until smooth, do not spend any more time than necessary getting this batter moist.  Meaning: mix it until it's just barely combined.  A few small lumps of flour isn't going to hurt this.  Bake them just barely underdone too.  In the case of mini-muffins, for me (my oven), it took 12 minutes.  I also left my bananas slightly chunky.  I have a personal preference for not so sweet things as well and the sweetness on this bake was just right.  It's all going to depend on the ripeness of the bananas though.  Overripe, I would have added less sugar.  This is a recipe I will definitely keep and probably play with later on.  I feel these would be phenomenal with a little cinnamon and some pecans. :-)
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
I doubled the recipe to get rid of all my bananas and I added one extra banana because they were all small anyway.  I used two dark 12 cup muffin pans, and I had to lower the oven to 325  about half way through cooking because they looked like they were going to burn.  I did let them bake 5 min longer since I had lowered the temp.  The muffins came out just okay for me, they did not have that moisture that I was looking for, but they do taste better the day after,  and my kids loved them.  Overall I think this is a quick simple recipe that can be tweaked around to fit your taste, I think next time I will throw in some applesauce, nutmeg and some dried cranberries.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made it exactly as directed and was blown away.  I also altered it with substitutions and had the same results. 
I substituted one banana for 1 cup of applesauce  and added 1 Tbsp. of cinnamon and vanilla. 
Also substituted one banana for 1 cup of pumpkin purée plus 1 Tbsp. of pumpkin pie spice and vanilla. 
I have also used half and half all purpose and wheat.  I've added walnuts to the mix as well as topped them with raw sugar and walnut pieces. 

I strongly agree with the others that say " do not over mix."  Whip the all the wet ingredients + sugar as much as you can ( I use my mixer on high for a few minutes), but make sure to stir together all dry ingredients and gently fold into the wet mixture. 

Each and every alteration has been as unbelievable as the last. Highly recommend this recipe as quick, easy and out of this world delicious.

I've tried so many banana muffin recipes I cannot count them and this by far is the easiest and most tastiest. I just made these. I added about 1/8 cup of brown sugar to the egg/sugar mix then after the flour was folded in I added about 3 tablespoons of caramel condensed milk just because I had some leftover in my fridge. Consistency is perfect- inside isn't too dense and the top of the muffin is just a tiny bit crispy. 10/10 will make again.

text:
So I just went through my first hurricane! Luckily I was not affected badly by Hurricane Matthew but it did make produce, and anything else refrigerated, fairly scarce. So to the cupboards and what is on hand I go. I used this recipe to do something with my old bananas, however I made some alterations.  I used coconut oil in place of butter and a flax meal egg in place of an actual one. I added a teaspoon of vanilla, simply because I love it! I also only used 2 large bananas, and added some walnuts, along with a good dash of cinnamon. Turned out amazing!! Will do again for sure

text:
This is an excellent recipe and I will be making these muffins often!  I took the advice of some of the other reviewers and added 1 teaspoon of cinnamon and 1 teaspoon of vanilla.  I used 1/4 cup of egg beaters in place of the egg.  My bananas were very ripe with black spots on the peels which gave the muffins a lot of flavor.  I stirred and whisked the ingredients instead of using a mixer and everything turned out great!

text:
I been using this recipe for years now. This is the only time I manage to give a comment. I have a 20 months old child who is a picky vegetable eater. I use this recipe to hide vegetables. I change a little though since I am making for my little one. I only use 1/4 white sugar and 1/2 cup unsweetened apple sauce to control the sweetness. I also added 1/4 cup of milk as well. I hide shredded carrots or succhini in it  which it works perfectly since he loved banana so much. I even sometime toss semi sweet chocolate ones in a while without vegetable ofcourse.  I definitely will recommend it. I tried so many different recipe but this one is the best so far.

I enjoyed making this recipe. I wasn't too pleased with the new yogurt I bought and didn't want it to go waste so I found this recipe! All were made with organic ingredients. Bob's red mill organic 100% stoned whole wheat pastry flour and unbleached organic cane sugar (for the kids, I'd use coconut sugar myself, it's not sweet enough for the kids) in lieu of the whites. I used organic Sun-Coc oil (it's so light and runs thin). The muffins were so scrumptious! Heavenly! This recipe is definitely a keeper.

20255430
Display Name:
JillB

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are absolutely delicious! I always DOUBLE this recipe and make the following modifications:

1) I use 1/3 cup of unsweetened applesauce and 1/3 cup of butter. The applesauce makes the muffins moister.

2) I add 1/4 cup of brown sugar, in addition to the 1 1/2 cups of white sugar. They don't come out too sweet and it gives the muffins a more complex taste.

3) I use seven bananas, instead of six to give the muffins a more intense flavor.

4) Like everyone else, I always add pure vanilla extract. I haven't added cinnamon or nutmeg, but I bet they would be great additions.

5) I bake these for 22 minutes, not 25. The muffins did not come out burned when I cooked them for 25 minutes, but they were very dark brown and I prefer golden brown.

This recipe is a perfect base and let's you modify it in almost any way you want. I have thought about adding slivered almonds or chopped walnuts, as well.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
Very yummy and definitely tastes banana-y! I added cinnamon, clove and nutmeg (only a dash of clove and nutmeg, and a TBSP of cinnamon) and it was awesome! Also Instead of the 3/4 cup of white sugar, I did a half cup of white sugar and 1/4 cup of brown sugar.  On the top of the muffins, in the last five minutes of baking: I mixed 2 TBSP unsalted butter, brown sugar, and a dash of salt and brushed it on the top of the muffins.  It gave the muffin tops a sweet, crunchier texture! Enjoy them!

None
country:
None
text:
These muffins are one of my favorite foods ever.   I'm only posting this review because I've tested it many times and find that I prefer two large mashed bananas instead of 3.  

Each time I make it with 2 bananas, the flavor is complex, buttery, banana...y, and sweet, and the tops of the muffins have the most delicate crunch.  If I make it with 3, I still have a great muffin, but it's not quite the same.

Lastly, use browning, aging bananas, as I'm sure everyone is well aware.

text:
These are really good. Great hearty taste & texture. I substituted to make a healthier muffin: 1/2 WW flour, 1/2 White flour, only used 1/2 c sugar (sucanat=lower glycemic index), added 1/4 c leftover pumpkin butter (could use any jam too), 1/2 c walnuts, 1t vanilla, 1 t cinnamon, 1 t ginger, 1/2 t cardamom, 1/2 t anise, 1/2 t fennel. Not too sweet or spicey- just right! Absolutely great w whipped cream cheese & then it's a complete protein w combo of walnuts, WW flour & cheese.

text:
The changes I made:

I substituted a single small individual cup of cinnamon applesauce in place of the margarine, and I baked for 20 minutes instead of 25-30 for 12 "big" muffins.

Next time I make this, I will most likely add walnuts to the recipe, and I might use wheat or white-wheat in exchange for the all purpose flour.  

The muffins came out very moist and delicious.  They smelled great while cooking and my kids were excited to try them.  I shared one with them and they immediately asked for more of them and for me to make the recipe again.  A definite winner!

I've made this recipe dozens of times following the exact recipe. These muffins are easy to make and have a rich full bodied banana flavor, especially when you use very ripe fruit.
In addition to making the exact recipe, I've tried different variations too. Using brown sugar and nuts, raisins etc. They all work very well too. text:
I am 13 years old and I made this without any difficulties! I had my dad find the sifter and that was all the help I needed! I consider myself pretty good in the kitchen because my mom taught me at a very young age . I did adjust the salt and sugar amounts. I used half the salt that the recipe called for and I also used about a teaspoon less sugar because I had very ripe bananas. I did use paper liners because I thought it would be easier. They turned out amazing! Not to sweet and not to dense. They were nice and fluffy! I did make sure that the bananas were mashed VERY well and I personally think that that made the world of a difference! I also read others' comments about not over mixing and I also think that made them better! 

Tips: 
-do not overmix 
-be sure to mash the bananas to personal preference
-adjust sugar to bananas ripeness/ sweetness
-add in only 1/4 teaspoon salt instead of the full 1/2 teaspoon

userID:
10192942
Display Name:
Crystal G.
isPro:
